ygData.msgSnippet: That s a great project, and very ambitious.  All of the inputs that you mentioned are important, but not equally so.  If you can handle all of those inputs I

X-Yahoo-Profile: zenguyuno

That's a great project, and very ambitious.  All of
the inputs that you mentioned are important, but not
equally so.  If you can handle all of those inputs I
think you should use them.  If not, IMO the most
important would be these:

* joint angles
* forces on body parts

Those are the things that an actual human being is
able to sense directly.

* overall center of mass

A human does not directly sense this, but can estimate
it from what he sees.  It is likely that he estimates
its velocity more quickly and accurately than its
position.

* body part positions (global coordinates or maybe
offset from the center of mass)

Those are estimated from the joint angles by the human
brain, and to some extent by what it sees.

* joint velocities

If you use NEAT, or another recurrent ANN, then these
could be deduced from rate-of-change of the joint
angles.  That is probably what the brain does.



=====
Mitchell Timin
